Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 11:44AM heatherb8 wrote: April and Margie..glad you found us and hopefully your mom will feel up to reading as well.  I'm so sorry she had such a hard time the first time..hopefully this time around is a little easier on her and perhaps they have given her additional meds to help her through the side effects..If not ask..you have to be her advocate...they sometimes don't offer up many meds unless you tell them they are not working..especially the neausea..they have so many options available and that is one SE she should not have to deal with..One of the ladies here stated once she started to feel some cramping she ate something small and that helped out the cramping almost immediately..small meals are key.  The hair part was tough for all of us, but once it came off and we started to wear the wigs, hats, etc..for me it was liberating and my scalp felt soo much better!  Sounds like your mom is very blessed to have such a fabulous support system.  God Bless You for being such a wonderful caregiver..it's definately not easy.. Momof3..Good Luck tomorrow..it's the anxiety of the unknown..once you go through one, that should settle down..if not I'm taking celexa and it really does help..calm my nerves and minimize the anxiety..Lisa's advice is spot-on do something for yourself today..whatever you enjoy most to help relax or feel good..pedi and mani sounds awesome to me..I haven't had my nails done since October and I am the nail girl..but once you get chemo you have to watch cutting the cuticles and such so nows the time :)!  Wave..hope you're feeling a bit better today..we are all thinking of you and praying your on the upswing soon..Hugs to you..In the words of my grandmother..."this too shall pass"..I live by it more than ever now.

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2012 09:01PM heatherb8 wrote: Josie..I didn't have too many aches this time..I was proactive on the meds...took a vicodin ever 4 to 5 hours for three days just in case..and not much pain..and of course took the clairiton..But it's normally 7 to 10 days before I'm feeling significantly better..hang in there! Whata..I never heard that stat..whether it's er/pr + it all starts from an abnormal cell which is fed by something er/pr + well we know what feeds it her2 - hormones, triple negatives I'm not sure..But the chemo will kill the multipling cell..No testing out there can test to the cell level..so you may have a clear mammo and mri and ultra sound, but again it can't get to the cell level..so the chemo will kill those cells and make it a non issue..after the tomoxifin will stop/minimize the estrogen and progestrogen production taking care of not over producing..radiation is of course only local to the breast effected so that cuts down any localized cells as well just another insurance policy..when I was considering not doing chemo even with a oncotype score of 23..my very good girlfriend who works in the breast center as an ultrasound tech at Magee Womens Hospital in pittsburgh..Instantly called me telling me all the physicians she worked with told her she needed to talk me into chemo..she was one of my deciding factors of going through with this.  If that many fantastic physicians are giving her that information I'm going to take it as a sign..I hope this helps..I'm certainly no doctor, but I did do quite a bit or research and never ran into that statistic..doesn't mean it doesn't exist though..I would be interested in reading more about it, although now what's the point I already chose to do it, but still would be interesting.. Bailey...thanks and good luck to you on Thursday!!! I know it's so hard when you're feeling so good, but almost done!!!! Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2012 05:38AM - edited Dec 2, 2012 05:42AM by heatherb8 Hello Ladies.  I was in the same place all of you were last year.  And a few folks already through the journey posted in our thread last year and it did make me feel a bit better.  The ride is not a pleasant one, but I can say going through all of this helped me reprioritize my life.  AT dx my son was 5 and I was 42 and it wasn't easy, but you get through it.  I had my head shaved right before Christmas and it was quite a liberating experience.  I had a lumpectomy, 4 rounds t/c, 31 rads.  I did not get the neulasta shot the first time and did end up in the hospital for a lovely 3 night 4 day all inclusive visit.  I suggest neulasta it's not worth the risk. You do get achy afterwards, but not horrible.  I wish all of you luck and the 2011 December sisters are a great resource.  If you have any questions I would be more than happy to help  if I can.  If I can't I am certain one of the December 2011 sisters can.  God Bless All of You! Heather

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2011 02:39AM heatherb8 wrote: Mercy4all..I felt the same way with being overtreated as well.  And prior to the Oncotype DX test that we are referring to..All women with the same diagnosis as we have would have received the chemo.  For me I had an 8mm tumor that was removed.  clear margins 2mm (the minimum) sentinal node was clear..so only one node removed.  no lympvasular invasion which is great.   However, I also had a cyst that was aspirated at the time of biopsy the fluid looked normal, but ended up coming back with atypical cellls..which means eventually that can turn to cancer. They had to remove the cyst area as well as the tumor and the cyst area was LCIS.  So because I had a second area on the same breast that had some "high markers" and due to the fact that even though nothing showed on the right side, nothing can detect to the cell level.  I did not want to have to deal with this again in say one, two, three, ten years.  So it was actually the other spots/issues I had that really was the tipping point for me.. Good luck on finding out about the Oncotype test, but the unfortunate thing with the test is the results take two weeks to get back.  Please keep us posted.  And good luck

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 09:14PM heatherb8 wrote: Hi Ladies..second treatment went fine today.  Expect the SE's to kick in after day three..once the steriods wear off..Uneventful with the exception of where the new place puts the IV..in the forearm..it's kind of sore.. Tomorrow the nuelasta shot..yikes, but they prescribed my vicoden to use for pain..my plan is to take one before I go along with the clairtin and try and nip it in the bud..I notice under Betsy's toolbox...she took the claritin the day of and five days after I believe... Thanks for the prayers, positive energy, and hugs from all of you...means so much to me and I hope I can keep myself out of the hospital this time. Ckk..i hear you on the taste issues..i didn't have a metal taste, but nothing tasted very good except for as others mentioned campbells chicken noodle soup..i think it was the sodium that helped..and popsicles tasted good to me. Wave..Sending hugs to you..It's not a fun ride, but it will come to an end eventually..My cousin had breast cancer 6 years ago (stage IV) and she said her first treatment was the worst and the remaining 7 she did where not that bad,  she went every week for something but the tough one (she did A/C) was every three weeks, that was the one that was the toughest for her...She did some sort of chemo for an entire year (she was HER2 + that was why).  .  So I look at what she endured and figure I can get throug 4..Are you taking any anxiety medication or anything.  I take celexa once a day which really does help keep the depression/anxiety at bay..Once I get through this I will get off of it..I also take a Xanax at night to help me sleep and keep dreams away..I think now I can probably go without it, and did for awhile until I was hit with having to do chemo and I got worked up and my mind wouldn't stop.  It definately helps. I hope your appointment went well today and they can give you some relief..getting up and moving does help, but it's getting the energy to even start..I don't do a whole lot, but do try and get up and walk a bit..it really does make you feel better to get the fresh air at least. I'm saying a big prayer for you as I do for all of us..keep us posted please. Lisa..thanks for your postive attitude and prayers..Your posts always lift me up..Thank you Thank you..It sounds as if you're doing quite well after the second infusion..That does give me encouragement.  The new place seemed fine..didn't meet with the doctor she was on vacation, but I met her plenty while in the hospital..Hugs to you my friend. Josie...I had the exact same feeling in my mouth..It was awful and it's starting to feel all dry the first day this time..I hated that feeling..It did go away by day 10/12 while I was in the hospital and then I got the dreaded huge mouth sores..so they gave me a couple mouth swishes for it..one was magic swizzle..which really numbs everything and makes it feel so much better for awhile..especially if you have a sore throat you can swollow some of it.. BJMRN..sorry you had to head to the emergency room, but I'm so glad you didn't get admitted..that was not a fun experience..my mouth was a mess too..I hope it starts feeling better for you..sounds like it is already in a short time..by the third week I felt really good..even after my hospital stay..The hair thing didn't bother me either after I had it cut short..not such a big deal..I actually went out for lunch today with no wig, just my fleece hat, I didn't want to wear the wig in while getting my chemo..it just gets too uncomfortable sometimes and well all the people there are in for the same thing!  Then headed to Panera after my appt for lunch with the hat..nobody stared at me..and if they did who cares! Ann..I'm so glad to hear your doing well..It's encouraging and you sold me on the claritin for sure!  I can't even imagine doing the taxotere every 2 weeks..I know it wouldn't take as long, but geez you need that third week to feel "normalish".  And I can't agree more with your closing statement..Many have done this before and more and made it through..and so will we!!! Bailey..good luck to you on Thursday..1/2 way there!!  My insurance didn't pay anything towards a wig.  Boo..they didn't even know what a cranial prosthesis was..Oh well I paid out of pocket..and it was worth every penny. I hope all are on the upswing with your SE's I'm sure I will be were you are next week, but really hoping not this time!!! Thank you all for being here and your support.  I think and talk about all of you daily..You are all great..and we will have to think of a place to meet once this is all over!

Made it through the 3rd tx..first vein blew and know I have a huge bruise, but they were able to find another that worked!  Thank goodness.  Only one more time for the veins!!!!  I agree with everyone on the 3rd tx..definately more tired right away..Normally the day of and day after I feel ok due to the steriods..not so today..But, "this too shall pass" and I will use Patricia's motto "keeping my head up".  We shall see what this infusion shall bring to the table next week..I'm also noticing my mouth going already..that was typically a day three thing for me.. Lisa and Wave..couldn't agree more after today or maybe if I'm lucky tomorrow everything tastes like crap..the only thing I can drink is ginger ale or vernors which is ginger ale just more gingery..and my local coffee shop (which I love their coffee, but can't drink any till about 10 days out after tx..really bad) they have loose leaf peach tea they make me with a bit of agave nectar..it's just the right amount of sweetness for me..everything else is too sweet or tart or just plain yuk..especially water..someone told me to try a squeeze of lemon, but I keep forgeting to buy one!  I haven't tried ice cream, but I did buy some Edy's frozen smoothies that you add milk to this time and some ensure so I will give it a whirl..going to start my baking soda, salt, and warm water rinses today and keep  them up better than I did last time maybe that will help..I can't stomach the biotine taste... Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2012 02:02AM heatherb8 wrote: Hello Ladies!  I haven't been on  here for awhile but I always try and keep up with everyone and I find myself looking at the facebook page!  Sounds like everyone is doing well..One week and two days of radiation under my belt..it feels a little sore and bitey (if that makes sense) at times, but I'm doing ok..I'm the youngest freaking one in the waiting room which gets to me a little..65 is the closest to my age..another man is 86 funny guy I told him I was 42 and his response was...wow..i have grandchildren your age..he has rectal cancer...his first operation will be at 86..yep that's what my life consists of now..yesterday after my labs I ran into the restroom and I always wear a hat (unless I have to look a little more normal) and a women in her late 30's grabs my arm and says do you have cancer..I was caught a bit off guard and said yes i did..what kind she asks..i reply breast..she replies I think I have colon cancer I'm having a colonoscopy today to confirm...she said she didn't mean to pry, but she wanted to talk to someone who was her age..so I chatted with her for about 10 minutes..i so understand wanting to at least "see" someone around the same age instead of in their 80's!!! Rachel..so glad you're starting to feel a little more normal..one more to go..take it easy on yourself and don't push too hard!!!  You have your whole life to run at a high pace!!!!  I will pm my email address to you! Ann...If you are having surgery today plese know we are all thinking of you! I too have 15 pounds lose..fortunately I lost 10 pounds at the beginning of all of this so I put on an additional 3/4 pounds plus the 10 I lost..just sucks!  I really don't care what the scale says as long as I can come down 2 sizes in pants I would be just ecstatic..ok I will take one size!  Trying to walk a little more..going to go ahead and get out there now  and I have got to do better at eating breakfast!!! So many changes to make!!!! Have a great day all!  Heather
